page.title: 08 BRIERDENE FARM
page.content: Agriculture has had an important part to play in this area for many years. Early settlers were atracted by its flat well-drained,fertile soil. Early farms provided foodstuffs for the local priory at Tynemouth and then the rapidly growing urban centres of Tyneside. Brierdene Farm is an arable farm situated 2.5km north of the growing conurbation of north Tyneside It takes its name from the nearby Brierdene which drains mineland and flows Eastwards into the N. sea. The farm is 500 acres,employs 2 full time workers and is extremely mechanised,with machines ranging from small grasscutters to large combine harvesters.300 acres are dedicated to wheat with barley and oats and oilseed rape being the other main crops.The busiest time of year is between August and September during harvest.
